title: Tribes East of Jordan
shortSummary: 1 Chronicles 5 details the genealogy, territory, and military exploits of the tribes of Reuben, Gad, and the half-tribe of Manasseh who settled east of the Jordan River. It highlights their faithfulness in battle, their eventual sin and idolatry, and the resulting Assyrian captivity, emphasizing God's sovereignty over Israel's history.
timeline: c. 10th century BC - Period of the divided kingdom after Saul and David, during the reigns of Jotham king of Judah and Jeroboam king of Israel

keyCharacters.name: Reuben
keyCharacters.description: The firstborn son of Israel whose birthright was forfeited due to sin, leading to Joseph receiving the birthright instead.

keyCharacters.name: Joel
keyCharacters.description: A chief leader among the tribe of Reuben, whose descendants are detailed in the genealogies.

keyCharacters.name: Tilgathpilneser
keyCharacters.description: King of Assyria who carried away the Reubenites and other tribes into captivity as a consequence of their disobedience.

keyCharacters.name: Pul
keyCharacters.description: Another Assyrian king whose spirit God stirred up to bring judgment upon the tribes east of Jordan.

definitions.definition: The special privileges and inheritance given to the firstborn son, including leadership and a double portion of the family estate.
A record or list of a person's ancestors, important in Israel for establishing tribal identity and inheritance rights.
A small shield used in hand-to-hand combat, symbolizing readiness and skill in war.
A biblical metaphor for idolatry, describing unfaithfulness to God by worshiping other deities.

outline.heading: The Loss of Reuben's Birthright and Genealogy
outline.description: This section explains why Reuben, though the firstborn, lost his birthright due to sin, and it lists his descendants, emphasizing the transfer of leadership to Joseph's line.

outline.heading: Territory and Leaders of Reuben and Gad
outline.description: Details the families, leaders, and geographic settlements of the tribes of Reuben and Gad east of the Jordan, highlighting their prosperity and organization.

outline.heading: Military Strength and Victories
outline.description: Describes the military prowess of Reuben, Gad, and half of Manasseh, their successful battles against the Hagarites and allied peoples, and God's assistance in their victories.

outline.heading: Expansion and Leadership of Half-Tribe of Manasseh
outline.description: Focuses on the half-tribe of Manasseh's settlement in Bashan and their notable leaders, underscoring their strength and influence.

outline.heading: Idolatry and Assyrian Captivity
outline.description: Recounts the tribes' sin of idolatry, God's judgment through Assyrian kings Pul and Tilgathpilneser, and the subsequent exile of these tribes, illustrating the consequences of unfaithfulness.

application: Recognize the serious consequences of sin and unfaithfulness, as seen in Reuben's loss of his birthright, and strive to live in obedience to God.
Trust in God's help during spiritual and physical battles, remembering that victory comes when we rely on Him as the tribes did in their wars.
Maintain faithfulness to God alone, avoiding idolatry in all its forms to prevent spiritual captivity and loss.
Value and honor God's appointed leadership and inheritance, understanding the importance of God's order in family and community.

keyVerses.text: Now the sons of Reuben the firstborn of Israel, (for he was the firstborn; but, forasmuch as he defiled his father's bed, his birthright was given unto the sons of Joseph the son of Israel: and the genealogy is not to be reckoned after the birthright.
keyVerses.significance: This verse explains the loss of Reuben's birthright due to sin, highlighting the seriousness of moral failure and God's sovereign judgment.

keyVerses.text: And they were helped against them, and the Hagarites were delivered into their hand, and all that were with them: for they cried to God in the battle, and he was intreated of them; because they put their trust in him.
keyVerses.significance: This verse shows the power of trusting God in battle, demonstrating that victory comes through dependence on Him.

keyVerses.text: And they transgressed against the God of their fathers, and went a whoring after the gods of the people of the land, whom God destroyed before them.
keyVerses.significance: This verse warns against idolatry and unfaithfulness, which lead to divine judgment and destruction.

keyVerses.text: And the God of Israel stirred up the spirit of Pul king of Assyria, and the spirit of Tilgathpilneser king of Assyria, and he carried them away, even the Reubenites, and the Gadites, and the half tribe of Manasseh, and brought them unto Halah, and Habor, and Hara, and to the river Gozan, unto this day.
keyVerses.significance: This verse emphasizes God's control over history and judgment, using foreign powers to discipline His people for their sin.
